description: Project Gutenberg is a non-profit organization dedicated to promoting free access to electronic works. It creates and distributes free eBooks online in formats readable by a wide variety of computers. Project Gutenberg digitizes and distributes works in the public domain and works with copyright holders to make their works available to the public. It holds a copyright on the compilation of its works and is associated with the Project Gutenberg Literary Archive Foundation. The organization relies on donations and volunteers to continue its mission.
Charles Dickens is the author of A Christmas Carol
Arthur Rackham is an illustrator known for his illustrations for "A Christmas Carol" and other classic books
J. B. Lippincott Company is a publisher that originally published "A Christmas Carol" in 1915

Bob Cratchit is the clerk of Ebenezer Scrooge in Charles Dickens' "A Christmas Carol." He is the father of the Cratchit family, including his son, Tiny Tim, whose health is a source of concern for Bob. Bob is a loving and caring father who is known for his kindness and generosity, even though he is a poor man with a large family. He is often struggling to make ends meet but remains hopeful and positive.  Despite his financial struggles, Bob is a hardworking man who is dedicated to providing for his family. He enjoys sliding down Cornhill on Christmas Eve and is often late for work, which frustrates Scrooge.
Peter Cratchit is a son of Bob Cratchit in "A Christmas Carol" by Charles Dickens
Tim Cratchit is the youngest son of Bob Cratchit in Charles Dickens' "A Christmas Carol." He is described as being disabled.

Ebenezer Scrooge is the main character and protagonist of "A Christmas Carol" by Charles Dickens. He is a miserly and cynical man who is the surviving partner of the firm of Scrooge and Marley. Scrooge is visited by the ghost of Jacob Marley and three spirits on Christmas Eve. These spirits show him the errors of his ways and the consequences of his actions.
Charles Dickens is an author whose book is available through Project Gutenberg
Charles Dickens is the author of A Christmas Carol
Arthur Rackham illustrated A Christmas Carol
J. B. Lippincott Company was the first publisher of A Christmas Carol
Bob Cratchit is the clerk of Ebenezer Scrooge
Peter Cratchit is a son of Bob Cratchit
Tim Cratchit is a son of Bob Cratchit.
Mr. Fezziwig is a kind-hearted and jovial old merchant
Fred is Scrooge's nephew. He is a jovial and happy man, known for his kindness and generosity. Fred hosts a Christmas dinner for his family and friends and is married to Scrooge's niece.
The Ghost of Christmas Past is a spirit who shows Scrooge his past. This phantom takes Scrooge on a journey through his past to show him the events of his past and the mistakes he has made.

The Ghost of Christmas Present is a supernatural being who appears to Scrooge in Charles Dickens' *A Christmas Carol*. This jolly giant is a spirit of a kind, generous, and hearty nature. He takes Scrooge on a journey through the present to show him the joy and happiness that he is missing.  The Ghost of Christmas Present also warns Scrooge that he has a chance to escape his fate if he changes his ways. By showing Scrooge the true spirit of Christmas, the Ghost of Christmas Present hopes to inspire Scrooge to become a kinder and more generous person.

entity_name: GHOST OF CHRISTMAS YET TO COME
description: The Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come is one of the three spirits who visits Scrooge in Charles Dickens' *A Christmas Carol*. It shows him the future if he does not change his ways. The Ghost is an apparition that reveals the shadows of things which may yet happen, offering a glimpse into a potential future filled with consequences of Scrooge's current choices.
The Ghost of Jacob Marley is a spectre of Scrooge's former business partner. The ghost of Jacob Marley, Scrooge's former business partner, appears to Scrooge.

Joe is an old man who owns a marine-store. He is welcoming and friendly, often appraising the value of items brought to him. While his shop is described as "rusty," Joe is known for his kindness and willingness to help. He may be struggling financially, but he is working with a group of people to secure money from a recent inheritance.
Mr. Topper is a bachelor
Dick Wilkins was a former apprentice who worked for both Scrooge and Fezziwig.
Belle is a comely matron who was an old sweetheart of Scrooge's
Caroline is the wife of one of Scrooge's debtors. She is relieved to hear of his passing.

Mrs. Cratchit is the wife of Bob Cratchit and the mother of the Cratchit family. She is a skilled cook who is known for her loving and supportive nature. Mrs. Cratchit is dedicated to her family and works hard to prepare for Christmas, particularly by making a delicious pudding. Despite the challenges of their limited means, she remains optimistic and finds joy in spending time with her family. While she expresses frustration with Scrooge's character, she ultimately embodies a spirit of resilience and generosity.
Belinda Cratchit is a daughter of Bob Cratchit
Martha Cratchit is a daughter of Bob Cratchit

Mrs. Dilber is a laundress and a woman who is present at a gathering in the parlor. She is described as "bold" and "defiant" and seems to be in agreement with the other women about the actions being taken. She is likely the charwoman mentioned in the beginning of the text. Mrs. Dilber is not afraid to speak her mind and judge others.
Fan is the sister of Scrooge. In the vision of the past, she is also the sister of Scrooge's younger self.

Mrs. Fezziwig is the wife of Mr. Fezziwig and a co-host of the Christmas party. She is an enthusiastic participant in the festivities, dancing with her husband with skill and enthusiasm in the "Sir Roger de Coverley" dance.
Fred is the nephew of Ebenezer Scrooge
The Ghost of Jacob Marley was Scrooge's former partner in business
Belle was an old sweetheart of Scrooge's
Fan is the sister of Ebenezer Scrooge
Mrs. Fezziwig is the wife of Mr. Fezziwig
Belinda Cratchit is the daughter of Bob Cratchit
Martha Cratchit is the daughter of Bob Cratchit
Mrs. Cratchit is the wife of Bob Cratchit

Marley was Scrooge's former business partner and friend. He died seven years before the story takes place and appears to Scrooge as a ghost.  Marley is described as wearing his usual waistcoat, tights, and boots. He also has a chain made of cash-boxes, keys, padlocks, ledgers, deeds, and heavy purses. Although Scrooge initially refuses to believe in him, Marley haunts Scrooge as a ghost with chains.

Scrooge is the main character of the story, A Christmas Carol, by Charles Dickens. He is a wealthy but miserly businessman who lives in a gloomy suite of rooms in London. Scrooge is initially described as being a cold, bitter, and unsympathetic man who is skeptical of Christmas and despises generosity. He is a friend to Marley, who is dead. He is also the boss of Bob Cratchit and is known for his stinginess and lack of holiday spirit. Scrooge is visited by the ghost of his former business partner, Jacob Marley, as well as the Ghosts of Christmas Past, Present, and Future. These ghosts show him visions of his past, present, and future, teaching him the importance of generosity and kindness.  Through these experiences, Scrooge undergoes a transformation, becoming a kinder and more generous person. He learns to value people and relationships over money and becomes a friend of Bob Cratchit and his family.
Marley is a ghost who visits Scrooge in the story. The story revolves around Scrooge being visited by Marley's Ghost, connecting the two characters.

Scrooge and Marley were business partners for many years, operating a company called Scrooge and Marley. They were close enough that Scrooge served as Marley's sole executor, administrator, assign, residuary legatee, friend, and mourner. After Marley's death seven years prior, Scrooge was visited by Marley's ghost, appearing as a vivid apparition in the knocker of his door and in the fire tiles.  The ghost's appearance suggests a strong connection between the two men, likely stemming from their past business partnership.
Scrooge is described as being especially unpleasant during the time of Christmas Eve, sitting in his office

Scrooge's nephew is a cheerful, kind, and good-natured man who believes in the importance of Christmas. He is known for his hearty laughter and his positive outlook on life. He is married to Scrooge's niece and hosts a Christmas party at his house each year. Despite Scrooge's dislike of Christmas, his nephew invites him to dinner every year in an attempt to cheer him up.
Scrooge and his nephew are family. Scrooge's nephew attempts to cheer up Scrooge, who is dismissive of Christmas.

Christmas is a festive holiday celebrated by many, including the men on the ship and Scrooge's nephew. It is a time of giving, forgiving, and charitable acts. People gather and exchange gifts during the Christmas season, which is a time for celebration and family gatherings. While Scrooge does not celebrate Christmas and even hates it, many others find it a joyful and meaningful occasion.

Scrooge despises Christmas and does not celebrate it. He finds no joy in the holiday and has a disdain for it. However, Scrooge does celebrate Christmas with his nephew and witnesses the holiday on a ship with a ghost. The Ghost of Christmas Present is trying to show Scrooge the true spirit of the season.
Scrooge's nephew loves Christmas and celebrates it

Scrooge's nephew is the nephew of Scrooge. He is deeply contrasted to Scrooge in his attitude towards Christmas and life in general. He tries to get Scrooge to celebrate Christmas with him by inviting him to Christmas dinner every year, despite the fact that Scrooge dislikes these invitations.
Scrooge and Marley's is a business that was owned by Scrooge and his former partner Marley
A mental asylum where Scrooge believes he should be sent because his clerk is happy despite his poverty
The Treadmill refers to the workhouse, a place where the poor were forced to work in order to survive
The Poor Law was a system of laws that regulated the care of the poor in England
Scrooge supports the workhouse, known as the Treadmill, as a place for the poor
Scrooge supports the Poor Law, which regulates the care of the poor
St. Dunstan is a saint who is known for his ability to control evil spirits
The Lord Mayor is a high-ranking official in London who is responsible for the city's governance
The Mansion House is the official residence of the Lord Mayor of London
Cornhill is a street in London.  It is known for being the location where Bob Cratchit goes sliding on Christmas Eve.
Scrooge is compared to St. Dunstan, who was known for controlling evil spirits, in a hypothetical scenario where he could control the cold weather
The Lord Mayor resides in the Mansion House
Bob Cratchit, Scrooge's employee, went down a slide on Cornhill

Camden Town is a district in London, England. It is the location where Bob Cratchit, a character from Charles Dickens' "A Christmas Carol", resides. Scrooge, another character in the same story, sends a turkey to Bob Cratchit's family in Camden Town.
Bob Cratchit is an employee of Scrooge and works as his clerk. Their relationship is complex.
Bob Cratchit goes sliding down Cornhill on Christmas Eve
Bob Cratchit lives in Camden Town

Jacob Marley is the ghost of Scrooge's former business partner, who died seven years before the story takes place.  He appears to Scrooge to warn him about his future. Jacob Marley is a spirit who is bound to a life of remorse because of his actions in life, and he cannot find peace. He is condemned to wander the earth, and warns Scrooge that he will be visited by three spirits.
Jacob Marley was Scrooge's business partner in life and died seven years before the story takes place. He now visits Scrooge as a ghost. Scrooge is visited by the Ghost of Jacob Marley.

Jacob Marley, the ghost of Scrooge's former business partner, appears to warn Scrooge about his future.  Marley's purpose is to encourage Scrooge to change his ways and avoid the fate that befell him.  While Marley is a ghost, he was once a successful businessman who partnered with Scrooge.  His message emphasizes the importance of generosity and compassion, urging Scrooge to reconsider his miserly ways.
The ward would have indicted the ghost for being a nuisance, as it made loud noises
Jacob Marley is a former business partner of Ebenezer Scrooge, and he visited him as a ghost to warn him about the consequences of his life and to give him a chance to change his ways
Jacob Marley's chain made such a noise that the ward would have indicted him for it
The Ghost of Christmas Present is one of the three spirits who visit Scrooge. This spirit shows Scrooge different scenes of the present day, and warns him that he is to be visited by three spirits.
The Invisible World is a realm where ghosts reside and interact with the living

Scrooge is visited by the Ghost of Christmas Past, who shows him his past and how his choices led to his current state. This visit, which can also be described as haunting, serves as a reminder of Scrooge's past and the impact of his actions.

The Spirit is a supernatural being who takes Scrooge on a journey through time.  The Spirit acts as a guide and teacher, helping Scrooge understand the consequences of his actions.  The Spirit shows Scrooge both the future and the impact his life has had on others.

Scrooge is visited by the Spirit, who takes him on a journey through time, showing him the consequences of his actions. The Spirit's purpose is to teach Scrooge to change his ways by showcasing visions of his past and future.

Fezziwig is a former employer of Scrooge and Dick, known for his generosity and kindness to his employees. He was a business owner who held a lavish Christmas Eve party for his staff. He is known for his enthusiasm for dancing, as evidenced by his energy and stamina in leading the "Sir Roger de Coverley" dance with his wife, Mrs. Fezziwig. He also encourages his guests to participate in the festivities.
Ebenezer is a character in the story, implied to be Scrooge's former self.

Scrooge is visited by the Ghost of Christmas Present, who shows him the true spirit of Christmas. The Ghost takes Scrooge on a journey, revealing the joy of Christmas celebrations and the happiness of those around him.  Scrooge witnesses how others are celebrating Christmas while he is alone and miserable, highlighting the importance of generosity and compassion during the holiday season.

Miss Belinda is a child of the Cratchit family, she sweetened the apple sauce and later changed the plates

Martha is a fictional character who appears in two different stories. In the story of "A Christmas Carol," Martha is a child of the Cratchit family and is known for dusting the hot plates. In another story, Martha is portrayed as a poor apprentice who works at a milliner's shop. In this story, she encounters a countess and a lord a few days prior to the events described.

Bob is a character in the story who works for Scrooge. He is the father of the Cratchit family and is grieving over the death of a child. He is late to work and brings Tiny Tim to his place at the table.

Tiny Tim is the youngest child of Bob Cratchit, a member of the Cratchit family. He is a young boy who is physically frail and described as being kind and loving.  Tiny Tim is a symbol of hope and innocence, demonstrating optimism and cheerfulness despite his illness. He is fondly remembered by his family after he dies. Tiny Tim is also befriended by Scrooge.

Bob Cratchit and Mrs. Cratchit are married and share a loving relationship. Bob holds Mrs. Cratchit's pudding in high regard, considering it a testament to their successful marriage.
Bob Cratchit is the father of Tiny Tim, his son. Bob loves Tiny Tim very much and is deeply affected by his death.
The Ghost of Christmas Present tells Scrooge that Tiny Tim will die if the future remains unchanged.

Scrooge is Bob Cratchit's employer. He is initially very strict with Bob and often criticizes him for being late to work. However, Scrooge later decides to send a turkey to Bob Cratchit and his family as a gift. He feels happy about giving the gift and laughs about it, as if it is a joke. This suggests that Scrooge is changing his ways to be more generous.
Peter is one of Bob Cratchit's children. He is also the same height as the lord mentioned by Martha. Peter is a young boy who is considering investing.

The Ghost of Christmas Present embodies the spirit of generosity and joy associated with the Christmas season

Scrooge's niece is a kind and generous woman who loves Christmas and enjoys spending time with her family. She is described as being "plump" and wearing "lace tucker".  She is married to Scrooge's nephew and shares his enthusiasm for the holiday.  She is known for her joy and kindness, and is a young woman who attends parties at her uncle's house.

Scrooge's niece is related to Scrooge, as she is married to Scrooge's nephew. While their specific relationship isn't explicitly stated, they are part of the same family circle.  Scrooge's niece enjoys spending time with her family, despite Scrooge's dislike of Christmas.
Scrooge's niece is married to Scrooge's nephew, indicating a close relationship between them.

target_entity: GHOST OF CHRISTMAS YET TO COME
description: Scrooge is visited by the Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come
The Phantom is a ghostly figure that guides Scrooge on his journey through time, showing him different aspects of his past, present, and future

Ebenezer Scrooge is visited by the Phantom, who guides him through time, showing him different aspects of his past, present, and future. The Phantom reveals the consequences of Scrooge's actions and even shows him his own grave.  Scrooge is deeply affected by these visions and pleads with the Phantom for a chance to change his life.
The Ghost of Jacob Marley is a former business partner of Scrooge and appears to him as a ghost
Joe Miller was a famous comedian in the 18th century. He was known for his jokes and stories. He is referenced in the text as a symbol of humor and laughter.

Scrooge, known for his miserly nature, demonstrates a change in character by sending a large turkey as a gift to Bob Cratchit's family, which includes Tiny Tim. The size of the turkey, twice that of Tiny Tim, highlights Scrooge's generosity.  Scrooge's act of sending the turkey suggests he cares for the well-being of the Cratchit family, including Tiny Tim.  This act of kindness, particularly finding humor in it, indicates a shift towards compassion. Additionally, Scrooge befriends Tiny Tim, further demonstrating a change in his attitude towards others.

Scrooge sends a turkey to Bob Cratchit's family in Camden Town. He is taking action to help Bob Cratchit's family by providing them with a generous gift. This shows a clear change in Scrooge's character towards kindness and generosity.
Scrooge visits Fred for dinner at Christmas. They are related by marriage.
Bob is an employee of Scrooge and is late for work on Christmas Eve, prompting Scrooge's anger
Scrooge is Bob's employer and gives him a raise in salary and a Christmas bonus
